title: Enhanced Idghaam Techniques
desc1_desc: When two letters come together in Quranic recitation, with the first letter carrying a sukoon (saakinah) and the second having a vowel (fat-hah, kasrah, or dhammah), one of four assimilation rules is applied.

Lessons.name: Identical Letters (المثلين)
Lessons.pengertian: This rule applies when the two letters are the same. The Idgham rule is used, merging the letters smoothly. If the letter is ن (Noon) or م (Meem), add a ghunnah (nasal sound) for 2 or 3 counts.

Lessons.name: Letters with Similar Articulation (المتقاربين)
Lessons.pengertian: This occurs when two letters share the same articulation point but differ in attributes. Idgham is applied here.

Lessons.name: Letters Close in Articulation (المتقاربين)
Lessons.pengertian: This rule applies when the letters are close in their articulation points but not identical in characteristics. The general rule here is Idhaar (clear pronunciation), except in specific cases.

Lessons.name: Letters Far Apart in Articulation (المتباعدين)
Lessons.pengertian: This applies when the two letters differ significantly in articulation points and characteristics. The rule here is always Idhaar.

Lessons.name: Letters with Similar Articulation (المتقاربين)
Lessons.pengertian: This occurs when two letters share the same articulation point but differ slightly in attributes. Idghaam is applied, merging the sounds harmoniously.

rules.rule: Apply Idghaam when articulation points are identical but attributes differ.
rules.notes: Practice to maintain clarity while merging.

Lessons.name: Letters Close in Articulation (المتقاربين)
Lessons.pengertian: This rule applies when the letters are close in articulation points but not identical. The general rule here is Idhaar (clear pronunciation), unless specific exceptions call for assimilation.

rules.rule: Pronounce both letters clearly unless an exception allows assimilation.
rules.notes: Clarity is crucial to avoid misinterpretation.

Lessons.name: Letters Far Apart in Articulation (المتباعدين)
Lessons.pengertian: This applies when the two letters differ significantly in their articulation points and attributes. In such cases, the rule of Idhaar (clear pronunciation) is strictly followed.

rules.rule: Always use Idhaar for distinct letters with no shared articulation traits.
rules.notes: Maintain the natural flow of recitation.

Quizs.question: What is the correct way to apply Idghaam in the phrase وَقَد دَّخَلُوا بِٱلۡكُفۡرِ وَهُمۡ قَدۡ خَرَجُواۡ بِهِ?

answers.answer: Merge the قَد and دَّ into one sound with emphasis

Quizs.question: What is the correct way to apply Idghaam in the phrase وَلَكُمۡ مَّاكَسَبۡتُمۡ?

answers.answer: Merge وَلَكُمۡ and مَّاكَسَبۡتُمۡ with a nasal sound

Quizs.question: What is the correct way to apply Idghaam in the phrase أَثۡقَلَتۡ دَّعَوَا?

answers.answer: Merge أَثۡقَلَتۡ and دَّعَوَا with a nasal sound

Quizs.question: How is Idghaam applied when identical letters are joined in recitation?

answers.answer: The letters are merged smoothly with ghunnah if applicable
The recitation is elongated for 6 counts
